topics.title: History and Evolution
topics.desc: Java was created at **Sun Microsystems** in the early 1990s by **James Gosling** and his team. Originally called *Oak*, it was designed for embedded systems but quickly became the language of the Internet age. Java‚Äôs core promise was **portability** (JVM), **safety** (bytecode verification, sandboxing), and **developer productivity** (automatic memory management).

subtopics.title: üèõ Java‚Äôs Lineage
subtopics.desc:
Java did not emerge in isolation ‚Äî it is the result of decades of programming language evolution.

- **C (1970s)** ‚Üí Provided low-level access, speed, and efficiency, but it required manual memory management (leading to complexity and bugs).
- **C++ (1980s)** ‚Üí Extended C with object-oriented features (classes, inheritance, polymorphism). It was powerful but still complex, with issues like multiple inheritance and manual memory control.
- **Java (1990s)** ‚Üí James Gosling and team wanted a language that kept the power of C/C++ but removed the pitfalls. Java introduced:
  - Automatic **Garbage Collection** (no manual memory management).
  - Strict **Object-Oriented Design** (everything is an object; single inheritance + interfaces).
  - Platform independence via the **Java Virtual Machine (JVM)** and **bytecode**.
  - **Security model** with classloader + bytecode verifier.
  - A rich **standard library** for networking, collections, I/O, and GUIs.
subtopics.inshort: üìå Java inherited C‚Äôs efficiency, C++‚Äôs object-orientation, and added simplicity, safety, and portability.

subtopics.title: üöÄ The Birth of Modern Java
subtopics.desc:
- Officially released in **1995** by Sun Microsystems (project started as **Oak** in 1991; renamed due to a trademark conflict).
- Vision: deliver **portable**, **secure**, **network-centric** applications for the emerging web and embedded devices.
- Slogan **"Write Once, Run Anywhere (WORA)"** ‚Äî compile to **bytecode** that runs on any **JVM**, decoupling apps from OS/CPU.
- Early web impact via **Java applets** (sandboxed code running in browsers through the Java plug-in). Though now obsolete, they showcased portability and rich UI on the web.
- Desktop UI stack: initial **AWT** (native peers, limited widgets) ‚Üí improved **Swing** (lightweight, pluggable look & feel) enabling richer cross-platform GUIs.
- Enterprise momentum quickly followed: **Servlets** and **JSP** enabled dynamic server pages, paving the way for **Java EE**.
- Performance story: the JVM gained **JIT compilation** and later **HotSpot** optimizations, narrowing the gap with native code.
- Strong standard library from day one (I/O, networking, utilities) made it productive for real-world apps.
subtopics.inshort: 1995 release delivered WORA via the JVM, popularized applets, introduced AWT‚ÜíSwing for GUIs, and set the stage for Java‚Äôs server-side dominance with JIT/HotSpot performance.

subtopics.title: üîë Key Features (Buzzwords)
subtopics.desc:
- ‚úÖ **Simple** ‚Üí Familiar C-like syntax; removed pointers, header files, operator overloading.
- ‚úÖ **Object-Oriented** ‚Üí Classes, interfaces, packages; clear encapsulation.
- ‚úÖ **Robust** ‚Üí Garbage collection, checked exceptions, strong typing.
- ‚úÖ **Secure** ‚Üí Bytecode verification, classloaders, security manager/sandbox.
- ‚úÖ **Platform-Independent** ‚Üí JVM runs the same bytecode on any OS/CPU.
- ‚úÖ **Multithreaded** ‚Üí First-class threads, synchronization primitives.
- ‚úÖ **Distributed** ‚Üí Networking APIs, RMI, later web services and gRPC ecosystems.
- ‚úÖ **Dynamic & Extensible** ‚Üí Reflection, dynamic class loading, modular JARs.

subtopics.title: üåç How Java Changed the Internet
subtopics.desc:
- Early days: **Applets** showed downloadable, safe code in browsers (now obsolete).
- Server era: **Servlets/JSP** made dynamic websites; led to **Java EE/Jakarta EE**.
- Enterprise: Java became the standard for large systems (banking, retail, telecom).
- Mobile: **Android** used Java syntax and libraries (Dalvik/ART), reaching billions.
- Cloud: Modern stacks like **Spring Boot**, **Micronaut**, **Quarkus** run microservices at scale.

subtopics.title: üï∞ Evolution Timeline
subtopics.desc:
- **Java 1.0 (1996)** ‚Äì First release; applets, AWT, basic libraries.
- **Java 2 / J2SE 1.2‚Äì1.4 (1998‚Äì2002)** ‚Äì Collections Framework, Swing, HotSpot JVM.
- **Java 5 (2004)** ‚Äì Generics, annotations, enhanced for-loop, autoboxing.
- **Java 7 (2011)** ‚Äì try-with-resources, NIO.2, diamond operator.
- **Java 8 (2014)** ‚Äì Lambdas, Streams, Optional, Date/Time API; huge paradigm shift.
- **Java 9 (2017)** ‚Äì JPMS (modules), JShell; faster release cadence begins.
- **Java 11 (2018)** ‚Äì LTS, HTTP Client, var for lambda params; modern APIs.
- **Java 17 (2021)** ‚Äì LTS, sealed classes, pattern matching (switch preview later).
- **Java 21 (2023)** ‚Äì LTS, **Virtual Threads (Project Loom)**, pattern matching for switch, sequenced collections.

subtopics.title: ‚ú® Culture of Innovation
subtopics.desc: Java remains a cornerstone of programming due to its adaptability, strong ecosystem (**Spring, Hibernate, Maven, Gradle**), build tools (**Maven/Gradle**), and the **OpenJDK** community. With **LTS releases** and a predictable cadence, Java continues evolving for modern workloads‚Äî**microservices, reactive systems, and cloud platforms**‚Äîwhile staying backward compatible.

topics.title: An Overview of Java
topics.desc: Java is a high-level, object-oriented, robust, and platform-independent programming language. Developed by Sun Microsystems, it follows the core principle of **'Write Once, Run Anywhere' (WORA)**, meaning compiled Java code can run on all platforms that support Java without the need for recompilation. This is achieved by compiling source code into **bytecode**, which is then executed by the **Java Virtual Machine (JVM)**. The **Java Development Kit (JDK)** provides the tools for development, while the **Java Runtime Environment (JRE)** provides the libraries and JVM to run applications.

subtopics.title: Object-Oriented Programming (OOP)
subtopics.desc:
Java is fundamentally built on the Object-Oriented Programming paradigm. This means programs are designed by creating objects that interact with each other. An object is an instance of a **class**, which acts as a blueprint defining the object's **state (fields/variables)** and **behavior (methods/functions)**.

- **Why OOP?** It helps in managing complexity by promoting modularity, reusability, and a clear structure for large-scale applications.
- **Modularity:** Code is organized into classes and packages, making it easier to maintain and understand.
- **Access Control:** Keywords like `public`, `private`, and `protected` enforce **encapsulation**, protecting an object's internal state and controlling how it is accessed and modified.

subtopics.title: The Three OOP Principles
subtopics.desc:
Java's object-oriented nature is defined by three core principles:

1.  **Encapsulation:** The bundling of data (fields) and the methods that operate on that data within a single unit (a class). It restricts direct access to some of an object's components, which is a way of preventing accidental interference and misuse. This is achieved using **access modifiers** (`private`, `protected`, `public`).

2.  **Inheritance:** This allows a new class (called a **subclass** or **child class**) to inherit the fields and methods of an existing class (called a **superclass** or **parent class**). It promotes code reusability and establishes a natural hierarchy between classes. Java uses the `extends` keyword for inheritance.

3.  **Polymorphism:** (Meaning 'many forms') It allows objects of different classes to be treated as objects of a common superclass. The most common use is when a parent class reference is used to refer to a child class object. This enables writing flexible and generic code. Polymorphism is often achieved through **method overriding** (runtime polymorphism) and **method overloading** (compile-time polymorphism).

subtopics.title: Two Paradigms: OOP & Procedural
subtopics.desc:
While Java is a purely object-oriented language at its core, it is flexible enough to support **procedural** (or imperative) programming styles for specific tasks.

- **Object-Oriented Paradigm:** The dominant style. Problems are broken down into objects that contain both data and behavior. This is ideal for modeling complex, real-world systems (e.g., a banking application with Customer, Account, and Transaction objects).

- **Procedural Paradigm:** The program is structured as a sequence of instructions or procedure calls. In Java, this translates to writing code where the `main` method contains a series of steps and calls to `static` methods, often without creating many objects. This can be suitable for small, simple scripts or mathematical computations.

A well-designed Java program typically uses a blend: the overall architecture is object-oriented, but individual methods may contain procedural logic to get their job done.

subtopics.title: A First Simple Program
subtopics.desc:
The 'Hello, World!' program is the traditional first step in learning any programming language. It introduces the basic syntax and structure of a Java application.

Let's break down the program step-by-step:

subtopics.title: Entering and Compiling the Program
subtopics.desc:
1.  **Entering the Program:**
    - The source code must be written in a text editor or IDE and saved in a `.java` file.
    - **Crucial Rule:** The filename **must** exactly match the name of the public class it contains (case-sensitive). For our example, the file must be named `HelloWorld.java`.

2.  **Compiling the Program:**
    - Java source code is not directly executed by the computer. It must be translated into **bytecode** (.class file) by the **Java compiler (`javac`)**.
    - Open a terminal/command prompt, navigate to the directory containing your file, and run: `javac HelloWorld.java`.
    - If there are no syntax errors, this command will silently produce a new file called `HelloWorld.class`. This file contains the bytecode ready for the JVM.

3.  **Running the Program:**
    - You use the **Java launcher (`java`)** to run the program. This command starts the JVM, which loads the `.class` file and executes its bytecode.
    - Run: `java HelloWorld`
    - **Important:** You do not add the `.class` extension when using the `java` command.
subtopics.code:
# These are terminal/command prompt commands
# Step 1: Compile the .java file into .class bytecode
javac HelloWorld.java

# Step 2: Execute the bytecode using the Java Virtual Machine
java HelloWorld
# Output: Hello, World!

subtopics.title: A Closer Look at the First Sample Program
subtopics.desc:
- `public class HelloWorld {` : This line declares a class named `HelloWorld`. The `public` keyword is an access modifier meaning the class is accessible by any other class.
- `public static void main(String[] args) {` : This line defines the **main method**, the entry point for any Java application. The JVM starts executing code from here.
    - `public`: So the JVM can access it.
    - `static`: Means this method can be called without creating an object of the class.
    - `void`: Means this method does not return any value.
    - `String[] args`: This is a parameter to the method, an array of `String` objects. It stores command-line arguments.
- `System.out.println("Hello, World!");` : This is a statement.
    - `System`: A predefined class.
    - `out`: An object (of type `PrintStream`) within `System` that represents the standard output stream (usually the console).
    - `println()`: A method of the `out` object that prints a line of text to the console.
- The curly braces `{ }` define the beginning and end of the class and method blocks.
